awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Assessment of Tornado Loading on Low-Rise Buildings Using Computational Modeling and Tornado Simulator Testing
awd_abstract_narration:
Tornadoes are a type of severe windstorm that repeatedly have caused devastating damage to the built environment in the United States.  Low-rise buildings, in particular, historically have been among the structures that are the most vulnerable to tornado damage. Failures of this type of structure are often responsible for the social and economic losses caused by tornadoes, including the loss of life and property, as well as the interruptions to many critical societal functions. The goal of this collaborative research at the University of Arkansas (UARK) and Texas Tech University (TTU) is to further advance the fundamental understanding of tornadic loading on low-rise buildings. The outcomes of this research can be used for the assessment of building performance in tornadoes, the design of new tornado-resistant buildings, and the development of retrofitting strategies to improve the performance of existing buildings in tornadoes. The research project will be integrated with educational and outreach activities at both UARK and TTU to raise public awareness of the impact of natural hazards, including tornadoes, on the built environment and society in general. At UARK, students will be involved in the research through the Freshman Engineering Program, and the George Washington Carver Research Program that provides research internships to students from Historically Black Colleges and Universities. At TTU, the project will provide research training for students in the Wind Science and Engineering Ph.D. program.  The research will also be incorporated with programs such as the Severe Weather Awareness Day in Lubbock, TX, and through partnerships with local K-12 schools and national organizations, such as the 4-H Youth Development and Mentoring Program, to reach out to both local and national communities. These research, educational and outreach activities will help make U.S. communities more resilient to tornado hazards.

To achieve the research goal, this project will utilize a research approach that combines the complementary strengths of physical experiments in a tornado simulator at TTU and numerical modeling based on computational fluid dynamics (CFD) at UARK. Unlike previous experimental and numerical studies that were conducted independently, the experiments and computational modeling in this research will be systematically coordinated. Customized experiments in the tornado simulator will first serve as the basis to validate and improve the capability of the computational model in simulating near-ground tornado-like flows and in capturing the interaction between these flows and generic structural shapes. The validated computational model and additional experiments in the tornado simulator will then be used to evaluate tornado-induced forces and pressures on low-rise buildings of various envelope configurations. Tornadoes of various structures, in terms of the swirl ratios and the maximum mean tangential velocity to translation velocity ratio, will be considered. The primary outcomes of this study will be in the form of pressure and force coefficients acting on different building shapes. These coefficients, as well as the raw data and the metadata, will be archived at both UARK and TTU and made available to the natural hazards engineering community through the NSF-supported Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure Data Depot (https://www.designsafe-ci.org/).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The major outcomes of the project addressing the intellectual merit and broader impacts of the current work are as follows:

Research Contribution:

  • In this work, a simple CFD tornado simulator model is developed without the mechanical components such as turning vanes, fans, etc. The wind field obtained from the CFD model is validated with experimental datasets from Texas Tech University simulator (VorTECH). In the future, researchers can adopt and implement the simple CFD tornado simulator model described in this work to simulate the wind field of tornado-like vortex for further research activities.
  • The simplicity of the CFD tornado simulator model also makes it possible to run the model and simulate the wind field of tornado-like vortex using a computer with very moderate configuration (such as 8 to 16 cores, 16 GB of RAM, etc.). So, the simple CFD model described in this work helps in expanding the outreach of tornado simulator model to a large group of researchers, who can employ it in their own personal computers and get reliable results within a reasonable timeframe without necessarily relying on high-performance computing.
  • Important tornado vortex features such as touchdown swirl ratio (ST), core radius (rc), maximum tangential velocity (Vtmax), elevation of maximum tangential velocity (zc) and pressure distribution with varying swirl ratios are identified for validation of CFD wind field with experimental measurements. These important vortex features strongly influence the tornado-induced pressures on the building and thus could be a used a suitable criteria for validating a CFD model.
  • Different tornado simulators from the existing literature are classified into 5 major categories (Top Full Opening System (TFOS), Top Partial Opening System (TPOS), Side Opening System (SOS), ISU, WindEEE dome) based on the recognition of similarity of flow pattern. This makes the comparison of wind field of tornado-like vortex in different simulators relatively systematic and easy.
  • The pressures induced on a building from the CFD model are validated with experimental datasets from TTU simulator (VorTECH). A validated CFD tornado simulator model that can reasonably predict the induced pressures on a building can be used as an economical alterantive to expensive experimental testing work in tornado simulator faclities. The validated CFD model can also be used to develop aerodynamic load database for developing wind load provisions against tornadic winds.

 

The list of journal articles that were published based on the summary of research contribution as described above is as follows:

List of Journal Papers and Extended Abstract:

  1. Kashefizadeh, M.H., Verma, S., & Selvam, R.P., (2019), Computer modelling of close-to-ground tornado wind-fields for different tornado widths, Journal of Wind Engineering and Industrial Aerodynamics, 191, 32-40.
  2. Verma, S., & Selvam, R.P., (2020). CFD to VorTECH Pressure-Field Comparison and Roughness Effect on Flow, Journal of Structural Engineering, 146, 9, 04020187.
  3. Verma, S., & Selvam, R.P., (2021). Effect of Height of the Tornado Chamber on Vortex Touchdown, In: Rushi Kumar B., Sivaraj R., Prakash J. (eds) Advances in Fluid Dynamics. Lecture Notes in Mechanical Engineering, Springer, Singapore, 495-507.
  4. Verma, S., & Selvam, R.P., (2021). CFD model validation with experimental tornado wind field & comparison of wind field in different tornado chambers, Wind and Structures, 33, 367-381.
  5. Verma, S., and Selvam, R.P. (2021). Differences in flow structures of tornado vortex and efficiency of different tornado chambers, 6th AAWE workshop organized  by Clemson University, available at: https://tigerprints.clemson.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1075&context=aawe 
  6. Verma, S., Selvam, R.P., Zhuo, T., and Zuo, D. (2022), Comparison of tornado-induced pressures on building from CFD Model with TTU experimental measurements,Journal of Wind Engineering and Industrial Aerodynamics, 228, 105076.

 

Educational Contribution:

Besides research contribution, the papers listed below were prepared for educating students and practicing engineers to be able to set up their own CFD models for evaluating wind loads on the buildings. For hands-on-learning experience, some Github repositories were created to upload and store the OpenFOAM case files so that the readers of the paper could visit the webpage, download relevant case files, and learn along by reading the paper.  

List of Educational Papers:

  1. Verma, S., Mansouri, Z., & Selvam, R.P., (2021). Incorporating Two Weeks Open Source Software Lab Module in CFD and Fluids Courses, Paper presented at 2021 ASEE Midwest Section Conference, Virtual DOI: 10.18260/1-2-1125.1128.1153-38325
  2. Mansouri, Z., Verma, S., & Selvam, R.P., (2021). Teaching Modeling Turbulent Flow Around Building Using LES Turbulence Method and Open-source Software OpenFOAM, Paper presented at 2021 ASEE Midwest Section Conference, Virtual DOI: 10.18260/1-2-1125.1128.1153-38326

Github URL:

  1. https://github.com/rpsuark/ASEE21-OpenFOAM-Introduction
  2. https://github.com/timusv5977/Straight-Line-Wind-Flow
  3. https://github.com/timusv5977/CFD_Tornado_Simulator

 


Last Modified: 08/07/2023
Modified by: Rathinam P Selvam

por.por_txt_cntn:
The major outcomes of the project addressing the intellectual merit and broader impacts of the current work are as follows:

Research Contribution:

In this work, a simple CFD tornado simulator model is developed without the mechanical components such as turning vanes, fans, etc. The wind field obtained from the CFD model is validated with experimental datasets from Texas Tech University simulator (VorTECH). In the future, researchers can adopt and implement the simple CFD tornado simulator model described in this work to simulate the wind field of tornado-like vortex for further research activities.
The simplicity of the CFD tornado simulator model also makes it possible to run the model and simulate the wind field of tornado-like vortex using a computer with very moderate configuration (such as 8 to 16 cores, 16 GB of RAM, etc.). So, the simple CFD model described in this work helps in expanding the outreach of tornado simulator model to a large group of researchers, who can employ it in their own personal computers and get reliable results within a reasonable timeframe without necessarily relying on high-performance computing.
Important tornado vortex features such as touchdown swirl ratio (ST), core radius (rc), maximum tangential velocity (Vtmax), elevation of maximum tangential velocity (zc) and pressure distribution with varying swirl ratios are identified for validation of CFD wind field with experimental measurements. These important vortex features strongly influence the tornado-induced pressures on the building and thus could be a used a suitable criteria for validating a CFD model.
Different tornado simulators from the existing literature are classified into 5 major categories (Top Full Opening System (TFOS), Top Partial Opening System (TPOS), Side Opening System (SOS), ISU, WindEEE dome) based on the recognition of similarity of flow pattern. This makes the comparison of wind field of tornado-like vortex in different simulators relatively systematic and easy.
The pressures induced on a building from the CFD model are validated with experimental datasets from TTU simulator (VorTECH). A validated CFD tornado simulator model that can reasonably predict the induced pressures on a building can be used as an economical alterantive to expensive experimental testing work in tornado simulator faclities. The validated CFD model can also be used to develop aerodynamic load database for developing wind load provisions against tornadic winds.


 

The list of journal articles that were published based on the summary of research contribution as described above is as follows:

List of Journal Papers and Extended Abstract:

Kashefizadeh, M.H., Verma, S., & Selvam, R.P., (2019), Computer modelling of close-to-ground tornado wind-fields for different tornado widths, Journal of Wind Engineering and Industrial Aerodynamics, 191, 32-40.
Verma, S., & Selvam, R.P., (2020). CFD to VorTECH Pressure-Field Comparison and Roughness Effect on Flow, Journal of Structural Engineering, 146, 9, 04020187.

Verma, S., & Selvam, R.P., (2021). CFD model validation with experimental tornado wind field & comparison of wind field in different tornado chambers, Wind and Structures, 33, 367-381.
Verma, S., and Selvam, R.P. (2021). Differences in flow structures of tornado vortex and efficiency of different tornado chambers, 6th AAWE workshop organized  by Clemson University, available at: https://tigerprints.clemson.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1075&context=aawe 
Verma, S., Selvam, R.P., Zhuo, T., and Zuo, D. (2022), Comparison of tornado-induced pressures on building from CFD Model with TTU experimental measurements,Journal of Wind Engineering and Industrial Aerodynamics, 228, 105076.


 

Educational Contribution:

Besides research contribution, the papers listed below were prepared for educating students and practicing engineers to be able to set up their own CFD models for evaluating wind loads on the buildings. For hands-on-learning experience, some Github repositories were created to upload and store the OpenFOAM case files so that the readers of the paper could visit the webpage, download relevant case files, and learn along by reading the paper.

Verma, S., Mansouri, Z., & Selvam, R.P., (2021). Incorporating Two Weeks Open Source Software Lab Module in CFD and Fluids Courses, Paper presented at 2021 ASEE Midwest Section Conference, Virtual DOI: 10.18260/1-2-1125.1128.1153-38325
